Problem:
Consider a quantum mechanics problem where a wave function \\(\\psi(x, t)\\) evolves according to the Schrödinger equation with potential \\(V(x)\\). We examine the situation where an operator \\(\\hat{O}\\) acts on \\(\\psi(x, 0)\\) before evolution.

If the operator \\(\\hat{O}\\) is applied to the wave function \\(\\psi(x, 0)\\) and then the system evolves under the Schrödinger equation until time \\(T\\), does the state at time \\(T\\), \\(\\psi'(x, T)\\), differ from that obtained by evolving \\(\\psi(x, 0)\\) without applying \\(\\hat{O}\\)?
Explanation: Applying the operator \\(\\hat{O}\\) initially modifies the wave function, potentially altering its components and how these evolve under the Schrödinger equation. The evolved state \\(\\psi'(x, T)\\) will reflect these modifications, thus differing from the state obtained without the action of \\(\\hat{O}\\).
